entry.summary: Instruments within the lab: Cryogenic PPMS ColdEdge Cryostat Liquid Helium Dewar DC Magnetron Sputtering (UHV) Argon Ion Miller RF Sputtering…
entry.content:
Instruments within the lab:

  • Physical Property Measurement System (PPMS):

Measurement system to study Magnetic and Electrical transport properties with benefits of:

  • Closed cycle cooling system.
  • Minimum lowest temperature of 1.8K.
  • Maximum highest magnetic field up to 9T.
  • A good temperature stability.

  • Coldedge (4K) Cryostat

  • Helium Dewar

  • DC Magnetron Sputtering

A standard magnetron sputtering system with benefits of:

  • A UHV compatible chamber of base pressure 3E-8mbar 
  • Connected with Residual Gas analyser 
  • Flanges with multi sputtering target connected maximum up to 4 no.
  • Dedicated UHV setup for metal thin film deposition only.

  • RF Sputtering

A small RF sputtering system with base vacuum 2E-6mbar dedicated for thin film deposition of oxide, non-metallic, insulator materials. 

  • Argon Ion Milling

A small AIM system with benefits of desired thin film milling of any materials.



Instruments placed at common facilities of SPS, NISER:

  • Focused Ion Beam

Crossbeam 340 system with multiple benefits of FIB, GIS, EBL and FESEM.  

  • Wire Bonding

A small wire bonding system dedicated for making electrical connections to thin film only.

  • Reactive Ion Etching

  • FESEM with CL and EDAX

  • Spin Coater

  • Photolithography

  • XRD

  • CVD

  • MOKE

  • TEM and LRTEM

  • CRYOSEM

  • Microscopes with different resolution and working distance

  • RAMAN and Photo Luminoscence

entry.content:
• Spin-triplet Correlations of cooper pairs in superconducting Devices

  • Spin-filter Josephson Junction


Most prefered material for spin current generation from spin imbalance in the band structure can be in a spin filter with a high spin filter efficiency. Spin filters in a josephson junction can reveal the feature of getting triplet or as an insulating ferromagnetic barrier for studying higher order harmonics also. Keeping all aspects open about it, modification or in combination with other materials, we can study the more reliable part of superconducting spintronics by combining ferromagnetism, spin orbit interaction and superconducting physics.

  • Proximity effect in superconductor-Ferromagnet nanoscale structures


 Proximity effect in S-F is very interesting 

  • Spin-glass Josephson Junction

The non equilibrium physics of a spin glass can not be fully understood until getting an idea about its energy state or any configurational state. Its randomness and frustration of spins make it more interesting. Since josephson junction is a very phase sensitive tool, one can put non equilibrium systems as a barrier inside it. The results from those devices will be rich and unputdownable in terms of superconductivity and spin glass physics.

  • Spin-orbit coupling induced effects in Josephson Junctions


The ferromagnetic material in a barrier while studying with singlet josephson junction becomes restricted as a function of its proximatisation length scale and its magnetisation increases complexity in making squid devices from it.  The righteous choice in a josephson junction is spin orbit interaction  by which we can generate, manipulate and control the spin near a junction area without having any remnants.

  • Proximity effect in Superconductor-Antiferromagnet interfaces

  • Single Molecular Magnet based detectors

SMM is famous for its quick magnetization switch caused by an avalanche in a correlated configuration state. Keeping this fact in mind we planned to fabricate some SQUID device to detect this flux change inside the loop.

entry.content: Superconductivity Lab was established  at School of Physical Sciences, National Institute of Science Education and Research (NISER) Bhubaneswar. Superconductivity has been an exotic property of materials due to their unique charge and magnetic transport properties. Thus, they offer a great potential for applications in quantum computation, detectors, spintronic devices, levitated transport etc.  Here, we intend to study the physics of various superconducting/superconducting hybrid interfaces, nanostructures and devices.
